awd_titl_txt: OP: Coherence and Energy Transfer Processes in Lattice Plasmon Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Lasers are ubiquitous in products such as readers for Blu-ray discs and bar-code scanners at supermarkets. Shrinking the size of lasers will enable their use in exciting new applications, from ultra-sensitive miniature sensors to faster computer chips to broadband wireless networks. However, understanding how nanoscale-sized lasers operate and amplify light remains a challenge. This work aims to uncover the fundamental operational principles of nanoscale lasers, given that their physical structure is significantly different from that of traditional lasers. Optics and photonics is a major NSF and US initiative, and broader impacts of this project focus on light and nano-photonics activities. Examples include introducing ideas in nano-photonics to the public by writing opinion pieces, serving the scientific community through editorial roles, and hosting hands-on activities on lasers and other optical phenomena for local high school students and teachers. Finally, drawing upon their editorial experience, the project leaders participate in workshops that focus on ethics in publishing and handling of controversial research topics.

Technical description: This project addresses experimental and theoretical studies of the mechanisms of coherence and energy transfer processes in nanoscale lasers comprising arrays of metal nanoparticles, in which surface plasmon excitations drive stimulated emission in organic dyes. To date, only a cursory understanding of how dye molecules affect population inversion at the nanoscopic level and lasing at the macroscopic level exists. This research aims to address this knowledge gap in nano-lasers using lattice plasmons as a model optical feedback system. Unlike in conventional lasers, quantification of loss in the cavity structures studied here is not straightforward. This project addresses a new approach to understanding competing energy transfer processes in the lasing action of lattice plasmon lasers based on coherence, cavity size, and ultra-fast characteristics. Electrodynamics coupled to density matrix methods serve to model coherence effects in these lasers.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal investigated experimental and theoretical mechanisms of a new type of nanoscale laser. We studied details of the coherence and energy transfer processes in plasmon lasers based on arrays of metal nanoparticles as the cavity architecture. Lattice plasmons are excitations that result from the coupling between the localized surface plasmons of the individual nanoparticles in the array with the diffractive modes defined by the array spacing. The narrow linewidths of the lattice modes associated with large quality factors and the high local optical density of states were exploited for nano-lasing at room temperature. 

To understand the mechanism of lattice-plasmon lasers, we investigated how lasing characteristics and dynamics depended on lattice geometry, unit cell shape, gain material, and nanoparticle material. We established hybrid materials systems composed of nanoparticle arrays coupled to gain materials including organic dyes, upconverting nanoparticles, and semiconducting quantum dots; all showed different exciton-plasmon coupling that were modeled and explained by theory. Controllable and rational emission properties of nanolasers were demonstrated.

Key outcomes of the project include: (1) continuous-wave upconverting nanolaser devices that operate at room temperature; (2) quantum dot-plasmon lasers that produce lasing emission with controlled polarization patterns; (3) tunable lasing action from a single device by manipulating the lattice geometry, nanoparticle symmetry, and plasmonic material in the nanoparticle arrays; (4) understanding of the competing dynamics of amplified spontaneous emission and lasing signals by ultra-fast measurements;  (5) determination of long-range (mm) spatial coherence of lattice-plasmon lasers; and (6) theoretical models of lasing buildup in plasmon nanocavities with open architectures.

This plasmonic system has promise in diverse applications and fields. Coherent nanoscale light sources from nanoparticle arrays coupled to hexagonal boron nitride, upconverting nanoparticles, or quantum dots have potential application in quantum information and lab-on-chip photonic devices. Nanolasing devices with dual frequencies can facilitate multicolor excitation processes in biological and chemical reactions, while stretchable nanolasers can be incorporated into wearable and flexible devices. Lastly, the generation of arrays of nano-localized optical fields can enhance weak physical-chemical processes on the nanoscale, such as fluorescence and Raman scattering, photocatalysis and other nonlinear optical phenomena. The Odom group actively participates in outreach activities including Nano Scouts Day, where the group hosts interactive nanotechnology demonstrations for local middle and high school students. Professor Odom is also an active advocate for increasing the participation of women in STEM through seminars at Northwestern University and discussions and presentations with local and international high school students.
